item.title: Morning coffee cuts health risks, but all-day sipping doesn’t - News-Medical.Net
item.description:
Morning Coffee Cuts Health Risks, But All-Day Sipping Doesn’t

Date: January 13, 2025 | Source: News-Medical

Drinking coffee at the right time of day could hold the key to a longer, healthier life—discover how your morning brew may protect your heart and boost longevity!

  • A study published in the European Heart Journal analyzed the effects of coffee drinking timing on mortality.
  • More than 42,000 US adults participated in the study.
  • Morning coffee drinkers showed lower risks of cardiovascular disease (CVD) specific mortality compared to all-day coffee drinkers.
  • The study emphasized that moderate morning coffee consumption might reduce mortality risk.
  • Key findings suggest circadian disruption from late coffee consumption could negatively impact health.

“Our findings highlight the importance of considering drinking timing in the association between the amounts of coffee intake and health outcomes.”

Overall, this study identifies the timing of coffee consumption as a potentially significant factor affecting health outcomes, emphasizing the benefits of restricting coffee intake to morning hours.

item.title: Winter Cold and Smoking Calls for Heightened Risks of Heart Diseases - News18
item.description:
Winter Cold and Smoking Calls for Heightened Risks of Heart Diseases

Date: January 14, 2025 Source: News18

The article discusses how the winter season and smoking habits significantly increase the risk of heart diseases, particularly for those with pre-existing conditions. Seasonal changes compel people to exercise less and can exacerbate cardiovascular issues.

  • Research shows a strong link between winter and heart attacks.
  • Cold conditions put extra strain on the heart, requiring more oxygen.
  • Smoking damages blood vessels and increases vulnerability to heart attacks.
  • Those with hypertension are particularly at risk for cold-induced issues.
  • Tobacco cessation therapy is crucial for reducing heart disease risk.
  • Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT) helps quit smoking, leading to improved heart health.
“Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT) is a proven method to help people quit smoking, which can have a significant positive impact on heart health.” - Dr. Sagar Verma

In conclusion, addressing smoking habits and taking preventive measures during the cold season can help reduce the risks of heart disease effectively.

item.title: How serious is bird flu? - The Hub at Johns Hopkins
item.description:
How Serious is Bird Flu?

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

As the first bird flu death in the U.S. raises alarm, experts provide insights into the risks and necessary precautions regarding the H5N1 virus.

Key Points

  • A Louisiana resident became the first U.S. human death from H5N1, contracted from exposure to wild birds and chickens.
  • Experts stress that the risk to the general public remains low, but the virus’s adaptability and mutation potential are concerning.
  • Preventative measures include avoiding raw dairy and meat products, and practices to protect pets and backyard poultry.
"At this point, we've seen no evidence of human-to-human transmission..." - Meghan Davis

The emergence of H5N1 in new species beyond birds, including dairy cows and other mammals, complicates tracking and management. Continued monitoring and education are essential to prevent outbreaks.

item.title: Risks of taking vitamin D in the wrong way and how to take it safely - The Times of India
item.description:
Risks of Taking Vitamin D in the Wrong Way and How to Take It Safely

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Times of India

Vitamin D, known as the 'sunshine vitamin', is crucial for bone health and immune function. However, improper intake can lead to severe health complications.

  • Vitamin D toxicity can occur from excessive intake, leading to symptoms like nausea and kidney damage.
  • Improper vitamin D use may cause calcium imbalances, resulting in kidney stones and cardiovascular issues.
  • Gastrointestinal problems can arise from incorrect dosages, especially when taken on an empty stomach.
  • Vitamin D can interact with certain medications, potentially reducing their effectiveness.
  • Consulting with a healthcare provider before starting supplementation is essential.
  • Prior testing is recommended to determine appropriate supplementation levels.
  • Vitamin D should be taken with meals containing healthy fats for better absorption.
“Avoid excessive doses unless prescribed by a healthcare provider.”

In conclusion, understanding how to take vitamin D safely is key to maximizing its health benefits while minimizing risks.

item.title: Health News Live January 14, 2025 : Trying to lose weight? Dietician says, avoid these five breakfast options - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Health Live: Trying to lose weight? Dietician says, avoid these five breakfast options

Publication Date: January 14, 2025 | Source: Hindustan Times

In this article, a dietician lists five breakfast options to avoid for effective weight loss.

  • Paratha with butter or ghee
  • Puris with halwa
  • Chana

For more details, read the full story here.

“5 breakfasts I would never recommend as a dietician," wrote Muntaha.

The advice from dieticians can be pivotal in the journey of weight loss, highlighting unhealthy habits and guiding better choices.

item.title: Bioengineers found breakthrough in building smart cells, potential to detect autoimmune disease: Study - ETHealthWorld
item.description:
Bioengineers found breakthrough in building smart cells, potential to detect autoimmune disease: Study

Date: January 14, 2025
Source: ANI

Rice University bioengineers have developed a new construction kit for building custom sense-and-respond circuits in human cells. This research signifies a major breakthrough in synthetic biology that could provide new therapies for complex conditions like autoimmune diseases and cancer.

  • The new construction kit allows for creating smart cells that can detect specific cellular signals.
  • This innovation could lead to immediate releases of customizable treatments in response to detected signs of diseases.
  • The research was published in the journal Science.
"Imagine tiny processors inside cells made of proteins that can 'decide' how to respond to specific signals like inflammation or tumor growth markers," said Xiaoyu Yang, lead author of the study.

This groundbreaking work suggests a shift in synthetic biology and cellular therapies, offering hope for more advanced treatments for serious health conditions.

item.title: Watching reels at night? Late-night social media use may cause hypertension, new study suggests - The Times of India
item.description:
Watching reels at night? Late-night social media use may cause hypertension, new study suggests

Date: October 2023

Source: BMC

A recent study has revealed a concerning correlation between late-night screen time spent on short videos and the risk of developing hypertension among young and middle-aged adults.

  • The study involved 4,318 Chinese participants focusing on screen time before bed.
  • More hours spent watching short videos at night increased the risk of hypertension.
  • Dr. Deepak Krishnamurthy emphasized the dangers of distractions from short video addiction.
  • Recommendations include limiting late-night screen time to improve sleep hygiene and prevent hypertension.
"Short video addiction does not only present a significant distraction but also helps in raising blood pressure." - Dr. Deepak Krishnamurthy

The findings underscore the need for individuals, especially the youth, to adopt healthier screen habits and lifestyles to mitigate the risk of hypertension.

item.title: Another child tests positive for HMPV in Puducherry, 3 cases reported so far - ETHealthWorld
item.description:
Another child tests positive for HMPV in Puducherry, 3 cases reported so far

Date: January 14, 2025

Source: PTI

Puducherry has reported its third case of Human metapneumovirus (HMPV) as another child tested positive. The Director of Medical Services stated that the latest case had symptoms of fever and cough and was admitted to JIPMER on January 10. Fortunately, the child is recovering well.

  • Third reported case of HMPV in Puducherry.
  • Previous cases involved children aged three and five.
  • Puducherry government is enhancing hospital infrastructure for better management.
“The child was recovering well,” - Director of Medical Services V Ravichandran.

This emergence of HMPV cases in Puducherry is concerning, and the administration is taking necessary steps to manage the situation.

item.title: Beat the Blues with your plate: Can a fibre-rich diet fight depression? - The Hindu
item.description:
Beat the Blues with Your Plate: Can a Fibre-Rich Diet Fight Depression?

Published on: January 14, 2025 Source: Unknown

Research indicates that a fibre-rich diet can significantly reduce the risk of depression, with greater benefits observed in adolescents. This article explores the connections between diet, especially fibre intake, and mental health, particularly in the context of rising depression rates in India.

  • A high-fibre diet is associated with lower odds of depression, with a 57% reduction in risk for adolescents.
  • Research published in Nutritional Neuroscience showcases findings from 18 studies on fibre intake and mental health.
  • Traditional Indian diets rich in fibre are essential in supporting mental well-being.
  • Modern dietary shifts toward processed foods may exacerbate mental health issues.
“Taking care of your mind starts with taking care of your body.” - Dr. Hemant Bhargav

In conclusion, prioritizing a fibre-rich and nutrient-dense diet may be pivotal in managing and preventing depression.

item.title: Sierra Leone declares emergency after confirming 2nd mpox case in 4 days - The Washington Post
item.description:
Sierra Leone Declares Emergency After Second Mpox Case in Four Days

Date: Monday, Source: AP News

DAKAR, Senegal — Sierra Leone declared a state of emergency Monday after the country reported its second case of mpox in less than four days, health authorities said.

  • Neither case had known recent contact with infected animals or sick individuals.
  • The first case involved recent travel limited to the airport town of Lungi.
  • Both patients are receiving treatment at a hospital in the capital, Freetown.
No known contact with infected animals or sick individuals has been reported.

The rapid emergence of mpox cases in Sierra Leone has raised health concerns and prompted immediate action from authorities.

item.title: ‘Even with a broken foot, I was…’: How Chhavi Mittal prioritised health and conquered challenges post-cancer - The Indian Express
item.description:
‘Even with a broken foot, I was…’: How Chhavi Mittal prioritised health and conquered challenges post-cancer

Publication Date: 2024

Source: Indian Express

Chhavi Mittal’s commitment to her health after battling cancer is a testament to her strength and determination, even as she faced challenges like foot fractures in 2024.

  • Chhavi shared her experiences on Instagram, emphasizing her focus on health and fitness post-cancer.
  • Despite experiencing multiple fractures, she continued to pursue physical activity and personal records.
  • Dr. Srinath highlights the importance of weight training for bone health and reducing fracture risks.
  • Precautionary measures are crucial when engaging in intense physical activities, especially after cancer recovery.
  • Structured goal setting and gradual progress in exercises help prevent injury and burnout.
“Setting SMART goals ensures realistic progress, such as increasing squat strength by 10% in eight weeks.” - Dr. Srinath

This journey underscores the significance of prioritizing health, gradual recovery, and the role of mental and physical practices in overcoming adversity.

item.title: Foods to eat and to avoid for better skin: Your diet to deal with acne, wrinkles or dryness - CNA
item.description:
Foods to Eat and Avoid for Better Skin: Your Diet to Deal with Acne, Wrinkles or Dryness

Publication Date: December 20, 2024

Source: Channel News Asia

This article explores the connection between diet and skin health, emphasizing how certain foods can exacerbate skin issues like acne, dryness, and signs of aging. Dermatologists provide insights on what to eat and what to avoid for healthier skin.

  • Acne: Avoid dairy and whey protein.
  • Signs of aging: Avoid white sugar and high glycemic index foods.
  • Dermatitis: Avoid spicy foods, hot drinks, and alcohol.
  • Dryness and dehydration: Avoid diuretic foods and high sodium foods.
“Eating a diet rich in antioxidants can help the skin recover from years of sun damage.” – Dr. Lynn Chiam

The article concludes with the encouragement to eat more foods that are good for the skin, such as antioxidants, omega-3 fatty acids, probiotics, and vitamins.

item.title: Making One Tweak to Your Coffee Routine May Lower Your Heart Disease Risk by 31%, New Study Says - EatingWell
item.description:
Making One Tweak to Your Coffee Routine May Lower Your Heart Disease Risk by 31%, New Study Says

Publication Date: January 8, 2023 Source: European Heart Journal

A new study suggests that drinking coffee in the morning can significantly reduce cardiovascular disease and mortality risk, showing a 31% lower risk of dying from heart disease compared to non-coffee drinkers.

  • Morning coffee drinkers are 16% less likely to die from any cause.
  • Analyzed data from over 42,000 U.S. adults.
  • Participants were grouped into morning coffee, all-day coffee, and no coffee drinkers.
  • Consuming coffee throughout the day showed no mortality benefits.
  • Timing of coffee consumption is crucial; morning consumption supports natural wake processes.
“Our findings indicate that it's not just whether you drink coffee or how much you drink, but the time of day when you drink coffee that’s important.” – Lu Qi, MD, Ph.D.

Switching to a morning-only coffee habit may help improve heart health.

item.title: Acceptability of intermittent preventive treatment of malaria in pregnancy with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine plus dihydroartemisinin-piperaquine in Papua New Guinea: a qualitative study - Malaria Journal
item.description:
Acceptability of intermittent preventive treatment of malaria in pregnancy with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine plus dihydroartemisinin-piperaquine in Papua New Guinea: a qualitative study

Published: 13 January 2025 | Source: Malaria Journal

This study assesses the acceptability of a new regimen for malaria prevention during pregnancy in Papua New Guinea.

  • The World Health Organization recommends intermittent preventive treatment in pregnancy (IPTp) with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (SP).
  • In Papua New Guinea, a combination of SP and dihydroartemisinin-piperaquine (DP) is being evaluated for effectiveness and acceptability.
  • Results indicate positive feelings towards the new regimen but raise concerns about the increased pill burden.
  • Healthcare providers express worries regarding adherence in non-trial settings.
“In the trial context, IPTp-SP plus DP was acceptable to both users and providers.”

This research highlights both the potential benefits and challenges in implementing new malaria treatment regimens during pregnancy, crucial for improving maternal health outcomes in malaria-endemic regions.

item.title: Johns Hopkins Launches Free Hearing Test App - The Hearing Review
item.description:
Johns Hopkins Launches Free Hearing Test App

Date & Source: [Publication Date Unknown] - Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health

The Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health has released the Hearing Number app, a free, multilingual tool available for iOS and Android that enables users to measure, track, and understand their hearing health as part of a global public health initiative.

  • Innovative Hearing Metric: The Hearing Number app introduces an easy-to-understand wellness metric, helping users track their hearing over time and identify when intervention may be needed.
  • Global Accessibility: Available in 28 countries and multiple languages, the app will soon expand to include Chinese, French, German, and Japanese, ensuring widespread usability.
  • Public Health Impact: As part of the Know Your Hearing campaign, the app aims to raise awareness about hearing health, emphasizing the importance of early monitoring to prevent and address hearing loss.
“The Hearing Number gives everyone a way to easily understand and think about their hearing over their lifetimes beginning as a teenager,” says Frank Lin, MD, PhD, lead creator of the app.

Hearing is foundational to social and cognitive health. Risk of hearing loss increases with age, and the app aims to help users assess their hearing health effectively.

The Hearing Number app is free and easy to use, promoting awareness of hearing health as part of a broader campaign.

item.title: Fixed-dose tablet shows promise against intestinal worms - University of Minnesota Twin Cities
item.description:
Fixed-dose tablet shows promise against intestinal worms

Publication Date: Late last week Source: The Lancet Infectious Diseases

A randomized controlled trial has revealed that a single, mango-flavored tablet combining ivermectin and albendazole could help control intestinal worm infections affecting 1.5 billion people yearly.

Key Points:

  • The trial conducted in Ethiopia, Kenya, and Mozambique showed that the fixed-dose combination (FDC) is more effective than albendazole alone in treating whipworm and other soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections.
  • In total, 1,001 school-aged children were enrolled, with high cure rates reported for both FDC treatment groups.
  • The FDC was well-accepted by children, highlighting its palatability and ease of administration.
  • The investigators propose using the single-dose regimen for mass de-worming and more effective 3-day doses for individual treatments.
“This is a pivotal trial that opens up the possibility of controlling all species of STH, including Strongyloides, and may lead to reconsider elimination goals that were deemed unattainable with albendazole alone.” - Alejandro Krolewiecki, MD

There are plans for further evaluation of the FDC in larger studies in other endemic countries and assessment of its feasibility for widespread implementation.

item.title: Sirsa MP Selja raises cancer concerns, finds reply by Haryana DGHS vague - The Tribune India
item.description:
Sirsa MP Selja Raises Cancer Concerns with Haryana Health Officials

Publication Date: January 13, 2025   Source: The Tribune

Sirsa MP Kumari Selja has expressed concerns over the rising cancer cases in Haryana and criticized the vague response from the Director General of Health Services regarding her demands for new treatment centers.

  • Selja's letter dated November 20, 2024, urged the establishment of cancer treatment centers in specific districts heavily affected by increasing cancer rates.
  • Approximately 3,000 new cancer cases are reported monthly in Haryana, with about 1,500 fatalities due to delayed treatment.
  • The DG Health Services outlined existing initiatives but did not address Selja's call for new centers in high-need areas.
  • The response highlighted ongoing initiatives and existing facilities but lacked concrete plans for improving access to cancer care.

No new info, just old data

Selja criticized the response for not providing new information or addressing the specific needs of the Ghaggar river belt.

This situation calls for urgent action to improve cancer care accessibility in Haryana.

item.title: Phase III Trial Evaluates Routine Tranexamic Acid for Bleeding Reduction in Hematologic Malignancy - DocWire News
item.description:
Phase III Trial Evaluates Routine Tranexamic Acid for Bleeding Reduction in Hematologic Malignancy

Publication Date: 2025
Source: Docwire News

The TREATT phase III trial investigated the regular use of tranexamic acid to reduce bleeding in patients undergoing intensive therapy for hematologic malignancy and severe thrombocytopenia. The findings were published in The Lancet Haematology.

  • The trial included 616 adults receiving intensive chemotherapy or stem-cell transplantation.
  • Participants had very low platelet counts (10 × 109/L or lower).
  • Results showed no significant difference in bleeding rates between the tranexamic acid group (31.7%) and placebo group (34.2%).
  • No notable differences in thrombotic events or veno-occlusive disease were observed.
“There is insufficient evidence to support routine use of tranexamic acid to reduce bleeding in patients with haematological malignancies undergoing intensive chemotherapy.”

The trial was funded by the UK National Health Service Blood and Transplant and the Australian National Health and Medical Research Council.

item.title: Shape & size of retina veins can predict stroke risk: Study - The Times of India
item.description:
Shape and Size of Retina Veins Can Predict Stroke Risk, Study Finds

Publication Date: [Date not provided] Source: The Times of India

Researchers have found that the shape and size of veins and arteries on the retina can predict stroke risk almost as accurately as traditional risk factors, without invasive tests.

  • The study published in the journal Heart indicates that the retinal vascular network mirrors that of the brain.
  • A simple retinal scan can assess the health of retinal vessels to forecast brain vessel damage.
  • Data from 45,161 participants over 12.5 years was analyzed, identifying 749 stroke cases.
  • Increased arc length and chord length of retinal blood vessels correlated with higher stroke risk.
"One can use a simple retinal scan to assess the health of these veins and arteries of the retina to predict potential damage to the brain's blood vessels." - Study Authors

This study emphasizes the potential of retinal scans in stroke risk assessment, promoting non-invasive methods in medical evaluation.

item.title: Longitudinal DNA methylation profiles in saliva of offspring from mothers with gestational diabetes: associations with early childhood growth patterns - Cardiovascular Diabetology
item.description:
Longitudinal DNA methylation profiles in saliva of offspring from mothers with gestational diabetes: associations with early childhood growth patterns

Published: 13 January 2025, Source: Cardiovascular Diabetology

This study investigates DNA methylation profiles in children of mothers with gestational diabetes (GDM), revealing associations with growth patterns across early childhood.

  • The study analyzed saliva DNA methylation in 30 children (15 from GDM mothers, 15 from non-GDM mothers).
  • 6,968 differentially methylated positions (DMPs) were identified postpartum, and 5,132 after one year.
  • Significant correlations were found between specific DNA methylation sites and growth-related variables like weight and BMI.
  • The findings suggest a stable pattern of DNA methylation that may serve as an early indicator of future metabolic risks in children.
“The persistence of these epigenetic signatures underscores their potential as early indicators of metabolic risk.”

This research emphasizes the importance of longitudinal studies in understanding the impact of maternal gestational diabetes on child health.
